name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Most children in general are not accommodated as much as they should be. All children have relatively slow processing time, and need pauses to understand things. 

The irony with autistic people is that most of the "trainings" do the complete opposite of accommodating us.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
It's seeing allistic interaction as the default, and seeing "friendship" as a neurotypical template that needs to be achieved, rather than figuring out what autistic friendship, or even ND friendship may look like.

It's about our way of doing things not even being considered.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I got a decent amount of pushback after I wrote an article about social skills & how the majority of "social skills" programs for autistic people (often run by NTs) are negative. "Well how do they make friends?"

A lot of what I'm talking about is subtle. It's phrasing & looks.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Autistic people get weird looks everyday - I get confused stares when I wear headphones but they are what I need to exist, especially outside and in public.

You have to counteract the public perception that enters our brains and hearts everyday just from existing.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
When people say "but what about the real world" or "But they need to learn.." or "but what if that's not practical.."

The question isn't what you're asking, instead it's

What do you do to make sure your kid has the confidence to be themselves & not apologize for it in 20 years?

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
If you want your autistic kid to feel accepted for who they are,

you don't just have to "not do the bad things" - you have to actively let them know that it's okay to be themselves everyday.

Even with really supportive parents and a "weird" family I still felt pressure to mask.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
@laurenancona Like I'm wondering if it is conformance for us, because we'd be fawning.

But to them it comes naturally so to me I'm not sure if I would call it conformance, if it's something they're doing to try to connect with someone else?

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
@laurenancona I honestly don't know if it is actually "conformance" - to me it's more like them sharing social bonding in a way that I don't engage in.

I'm thinking a lot about A Field Guide to Earthlings: An autistic view of neurotypical behavior by Ian Ford.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: @NeoWestchester Yea this rings a bell honestly. Mine was mostly that I hated school though.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
@laurenancona I'm saying there's not a noun version of it.

Would you be calling the kid a "neuroconformity kid"?

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
@laurenancona "Neurocomformity" isn't a brain type though - it's not describing the actual kids who tapped the box. That's my point. We still need a term to describe those kids.

I'm not arguing that "neurocomformity" is a bad word, I'm saying we still need a label for them.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: @laurenancona I'm not saying we need to use the word "neurotypical" at all, I'm just saying that we do need a term for people's whose brain work that way. Getting rid of that concept altogether isn't necessarily helpful.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: @laurenancona It's not an ideal - but it's "typical" because society is built around it specifically. It's not because it's better or even "normal" but it's because it is normal -to our society-.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: @laurenancona The most eye-opening and helpful thing for me personally was to learn how non-autistic people think, perceive, and interact with the world. It IS different. It's very different! There are in fact people who have brains that benefit from the society we live in, giving advantages.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
@laurenancona If I'm thinking of a specific example, it's the "tap the box" experiment.

Allistic kids saw a researcher tap the box 3 times before opening it. So they did that themselves.

Autistic kids went, "why would we need to do that?"

That's the difference I think of when I think of NTs

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: @laurenancona The only reason the label autistic or ADHD exists is because it Does diverge - from something else. I wouldn't say it needs to be called "neurotypical" - but we need to acknowledge that there are in fact certain brains that subconsciously learn and upkeep social norms they learn.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: @laurenancona This may be a "hot take" - but I do think there are people who do have "neurotypical brains" - even if neurotypical isn't the right word to use. I.e. there are people who have a specific type of social subconscious processing, project it onto others, and talk only in symbols.

I befriended her because.. I didn't have any friends and she was nice and didn't judge me as weird.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Maybe autistic kids really are "little adults" -

only in the way that many of them often emphasize with people regardless of who they are, and try to make them happy and try to feel validated in their lives by doing the best they can or hiding distress. That's adult, right?

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: I wonder how many autistic kids feel like they are obligated to keep the adults around them happy or comfortable in their lives because they know when they are distressed that people around them get upset and sad and don't know how to support them.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Even supportive parents who are trying really hard to help, 

as an autistic kid you can just tell that your parent is exasperated and you know the way to "help" is to not "act out" and instead to pretend things are fine (which takes a lot of energy).

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
One of the inherent struggles with being autistic and people expecting you to mask all the time is that you get really good at both telling yourself and the people around you that you're doing okay, no matter what.

Learning that by age 7 or 8 is not healthy.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
In no way am I saying white cis autistic women's experiences aren't valid (they are!) -

I'm saying that we cannot just focus on one marginalized group and create a diagnostic test -just for them-

meanwhile leaving trans people & BIPOC (& even cis men) in the dust in the process

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
It's telling that the first comments I got are from autistic women talking about their experiences..

I get it, women are overlooked!

But so are people like me (nonbinary, not a woman!) and trans people and especially BIPOC.

"Women" isn't the only marginalized category here.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

tweet:

Dove Orchids is about establishing autistic people as the experts and moving us out of the charity box.

Because we deserve to be paid for our contributions and insights and help!

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
All of those statements are not at odds at each other, in fact they provide the nuance that we need to frame our education with.

The true issue is lack of understanding and lack of acknowledgment that autistic people are the ones who understand their own experiences.

5/5

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
We can acknowledge that it is hard to be a parent, full stop.

We can acknowledge that it is hard to be a parent of any kid our society doesn't understand and accept.

We also need and MUST acknowledge that it is hard to be the kid that no one understands.

4/5

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Being that kid and being a parent of another kid like that is also, absurdly difficult.

The populations that exist are not strictly "neurotypical parent of autistic kid" and then "autistic adult."

There are not only two categories here. There's a lot more nuance than that.

3/5

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
And to be clear, I don't think I've seen any autistic adults who don't have kids say otherwise.

Those things are all true.

But also -
Being a kid that the world doesn't understand, whose parents' don't have proper support or understanding, is also absurdly difficult.

2/5

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Something I don't see a lot when it comes to talking about parents of autistic kids -

Parenting in general is hard, no matter what.

Parenting a kid that the world doesn't understand, without proper support, is extra hard.

Those things are absolutely true -

1/5

I'm not sure there's a real moral to this story, except that it took me 17 years to learn that some people (maybe many allistic people?) actually think about nothing, which was previously unfathomable to me until then. I guess I'm lucky, I did learn to think about nothing.

4/4

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I would literally think all the time. I would count steps, have a song playing, think about anything and everything (I'm sure it helped me dissociate from the school environment to some extent). I'd read a book if I felt like I wasn't "doing" anything basically anywhere.

3/4

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

tweet:
I think that conversation started it:

I spent the next year or two trying to figure out how to think about nothing.

I honestly don't know how I did it, but at some point I thought "well I don't think much when I watch TV, so why don't I try to replicate that?"

2/4

Me: What are you thinking about right now?

Them: Yea, nothing.

tweet:
So there's no way to connect because any connection might be painful for the other person, or they may feel we're acting "cold" or "detached." And if we break into tears because the wall broke, suddenly we're too much. It's such a solitary process for us.

11/11

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
The big concern I think for many of us is talking to other people. They don't want an explanation. They don't want to hear about the medical side of things. I was lucky to talk to a friend who knew a lot and wouldn't judge me. But then the worry is about hurting others.

10/11

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I don't even know how to grieve because I don't know what it looks like. I just know what non-autistic people are supposed to do. Even non-autistic people get policed and told how to grieve, when, where, how much time to take off. I just feel conflict in my body.

9/11

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

8/11

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

But it's built into me in ways I never knew.

7/11

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

I can't even grieve the way I would because it's been conditioned out of me.

6/11

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

5/11

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

4/11

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

3/11

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

2/11

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
[death]
You know, it's fine when I know people in my family or extended family are going to die, I can "handle" that. I can prepare for that. I'm still prepared for that.

But it's another thing when an extended family dies instantaneously when we thought they'd be fine.

1/3

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

tweet:

If you think an autistic person is coping as a kid, that they don't "need support" then it's just pushing their needs and emotional development back by 10-20 years.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

tweet: I see people thinking that it is "good" that their autistic child can cope and that they have learned the language of neurotypical society and all that does is make me sad for the future when they have to figure out who they are and how to listen to their needs all over again.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

tweet:
I would just like to remind the general public that everyday, 

autistic people are told that masking is good for us. That it gives us things, that it allows us to live in our society.

It's not. It's a pick-your-poison scenario. It's not "good." It's short-term and erodes us.

I used a laced-up ankle brace for a year for an injury and it was like $20 at most and still works.

& an ankle brace doesn't hurt either.

This -

People may assume that when we talk about autistic trauma, we're talking about direct or intentional harm.

For me, 99% of the time it was from someone who loved me and supported me and thought they were helping or were trying to help me. None of it was intentional. https://t.co/13dPXIy2Nk

How to minimize:
Don't worry about it.
It's not a big deal.
Why does it matter?

How to maximize:
Your concerns are real.

I'm here if you want to vent or want someone to just listen.
Let me know if you want any advice.

3/7

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

2/7

6/7

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA

it feels, at least for the majority of autistic people, to be inauthentic

5/7

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

4/7

you learn to hide whatever it is that pisses off the people around you.

3/7

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Would listening to music help with misophonia? Probably. 

Will meditating and listening to music help with every single auditory condition an autistic person has, or every type of auditory condition?

Very, very likely not.

7/9

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
It's almost like it's not something I can willfully control and is not based on my levels of stress or tiredness! 

And that's why things like this are a bit scary to me, especially when they advertise that it will help for "auditory sensitivity" which could be anything.

6/9

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Not with music, but I thought I could "will" myself out of hyperacusis growing up by maintaining calmness. I'd tell myself to take deep breaths and that I was okay, it's just sound.

And it was 100% just as painful as when I didn't do that.

5/9

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
4. It puts the onus on the autistic kid to "calm down" rather than prioritizing changing the environment the person is in.

I've had hyperacusis forever. It is not going to go away because I listened to some calm music or meditated.

I tried the "calm" strategy before even.

4/9

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
My major qualm with these kind of management strategies is that
1. It's not always by consent.
2. Meditation doesn't work for every autistic person.
3. It's a one-size-fits-all solution for any and every auditory condition for autistic kids.

3/9

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I'm not against anything that could be helpful to someone and isn't harming them or others. 

I think listening to music can help some autistic people with certain auditory conditions (if the music is their choice), and could even help with some anxiety.

2/9

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

but quite a few people are now offering these sort of meditation and listening treatments for auditory conditions in autistic people (mostly kids).

1/9

Daily support (for chores, errands, doctor appointments)

Cards explaining autism

9/9

tweet:
If anyone is wondering "Why does everyone assume autistic people are all children?"

Research papers on autism since 2012:

Childhood: 22352
Adolescence: 4422
Adulthood: 6750
Older Age: 136

Papers on autistic adults are 20.5% of all autism research, 

and that's for 2012 onward. https://t.co/ScYA2zO36t

*pause*
Person: *moves on*

tweet:
Autistic people *may* look very different in different contexts:

1. Being alone
2. Being with other autistic people only (with no hierarchy involved)
3. Being with general close friends (ND and NT)
4. Being in a small group of strangers
5. Being at a large event with strangers

Autistic framing matters.

6/8

5/8

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

tweet:

4/8

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

tweet:

& you still aren't autistic.

3/8

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

You can be the best ally, most supportive allistic person but that does not mean you are autistic or have the lived experience of an autistic person.

You might be a great ally. You still are not autistic.

2/8

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
If that doctor wants the real answer to why I cried after being told to exercise more,

That's why I cried. Because I will have to explain this to every doctor, every human being, for the rest of my life, and they'll look at me and still say "I don't understand."

That's why.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I think about the amount of energy I devote to thinking, planning, stepping, walking, how vigilante I have to be to not wake up and have that stepping-on-a-nail pain.

And then I remember that no one around me has to do that, no one really understands, and no one really cares.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I think about the countless problem solving I had to do by myself, alone, because doctors gave me the completely wrong advice, which would've made my pain worse, not better.

I think about the fact that I need to make a new mold soon for my silicone foot arch as it's wearing down

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I think about how many days I spent in foot pain, went to bed with foot pain, woke up with foot pain, for no real reason other than to not feel like a burden to other people. 

I think about how I walked for months with this permanent injury until touching my foot felt like nails

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: I think of the many times I waited for the shuttle because it took me so long to get a disability placard. I think about how people left me behind on short walks because I walk too slow. I think about how little I cared for myself and just did whatever I could to please others.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: I think about how I sacrificed my own mental fortitude and well-being to obtain external validation and finish data collection, to be "successful." I think about how I told myself, this is just what I have to do to get this done. I think about how many resources went to my pain.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
When other people "pushed me" for me, it ended up in meltdowns or trauma because I knew I wasn't ready but they didn't believe me, and I couldn't articulate why.

When I was given time and space, I could figure out what did and didn't work for me in a healthy way.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I think there's an assumption that people have to "be pushed" to get outside their comfort zone, with so often in my life the opposite was true:

If people stopped pushing, I could figure out where my boundaries were and where I could push myself.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Also - what ended up happening with me and rollercoasters was this:

I was never forced to go on another rollercoaster again and was in charge of what I wanted to go on. I ended up finding rollercoasters that I -did- enjoy, but I never went on that big drop one ever again.

But for "traditional" societal milestones I placed less meaning on it than NTs would.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I find that the more overwhelming the event is, or the bigger change, the less likely I'll be able to talk about it. And I may just not want to talk about it at all because it is so overwhelming.

People ask "How do you feel?" after big millstones & I just shrug everytime.

5/5

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

tweet:

It may just mean that they're processing and need time to figure out how they feel and what to say.

4/5

3/5

2/5

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

I would love if autistic people got proper "treatment" - which means screening for hyperacusis, hypermobility, dyspraxia, dyslexia, ADHD, seizures, and other common co-occurring conditions.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

I sit here thinking, what treatments? What do they actually mean?

Definition of treat:
"give medical care or attention to; try to heal or cure."

tweet:
When the reality is:

Neurotypical people have subconscious social processing that you are never going to be able to 100% predict, and people will get mad at you for being yourself.

And you might find some people who interact the same way you do. Focus on those people instead.

tweet:
Just to really reiterate on this:

When you tell autistic children that there are social skills they can learn, what they may hear is:

If you try hard enough, people will like you!
If you change who you are, people will like you!
If people don't like you, it's your fault!

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Autistic people are no more failures when miscommunicating with allistic people than allistic people are failures at communicating with autistics.

A lot of attempts to "help" by telling us there are rules everyone follows is honestly almost like gaslighting, because there's not.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
The idea that our society (within each person's culture) has a set of "rules" that if we follow, means we won't be bullied or discriminated against is, for the most part, nonsense.

And this idea that there are rules puts the onus on us and makes us feel like failures.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: The only "formula" is the subconscious processing of a neurotypical person, and there's not going to be thorough, clear research on that which is readable and understandable to autistic people for a long, long time.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
For YEARS I thought "If I just get the right tone of voice" or "if I just try to word it this way.." or "if I just smile more maybe people will think I'm approachable"

Still to this day I have to remind myself that There Are No Rules. There's not! There's no formula.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Like, non-autistic people, let's just be honest here, okay?

There are no rules. There are "feelings" and "instincts" that are subconsciously processed and the output is facial expression, tone of voice, body language, and words which show social intent and goals. 

Not rules.

tweet: @ActivistHat_ Totally - but I've also spent much more time understanding and learning non-autistic people's communication than allistic people have spent learning mine.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I went 24 years not knowing what eye contact actually meant (looking at someone's pupils!) and apparently most of the people around me thought I made eye contact! 

When researchers stared at NT participants mouths, they still assumed researchers "made eye contact" (they didn't).

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
It was also weird how confident some of the allistic people commenting were about reading people "well." How would someone even know if that's true??

There's research showing that NTs who are very confident are often wrong & aren't even accurate about others using eye contact.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

You could be acting the same exact way, but one day you say "I'm autistic" - and they suddenly treat you completely differently (what I've heard from others is often infantilizing them), or assume more negative intent. 

So is it really us that needs to change?

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I'll also say this - anyone who has had to disclose being autistic to other people, especially people who don't know anything about autism, can see a very obvious shift in how they're perceived.

And it's not everyone - but there are definitely people who change how they act.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
It's like, look, we're just people. We're not the "next stage of human evolution" and we're not "savants" and we're not "tragedies" or "lost in our own worlds."

Like, we're just people.. Is that what some people are missing when they talk about autism? Honestly, I don't know.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: Heck, maybe if "Autistic people are human beings, just like you" was the motto, non-autistic people would be more likely to think about why someone is hitting their head, and figuring out how to communicate with autistic nonspeakers, I don't know. We have to start at square one.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: This isn't a response to anything in particular by the way, this is just my late night thoughts happening and me being like "this is a super good idea to type out on the internet right now." Yep..

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
And one of the worst things is that autistic people do this to each other too.

And the main reason is because most of the "representation" we have isn't representation at all - it's non-autistic people saying things.

If we had broader representation, it wouldn't be an issue.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

tweet: Imagine a non-autistic person saying "I really don't like vanilla ice cream" and an autistic person replying "Well I don't know, you can't speak for all non-autistic people. Not every non-autistic person doesn't like vanilla ice cream!" and that's just all of social media.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

yes, autistic people are different from each other, just like non-autistic people are different from each other.

But instead it's like "no autistic person can say anything about their own experience because they don't speak for all"

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

tweet: These are the times when I wish people would understand hyperacusis. Just once. I'm not ignoring you, I'm not listening to music and distracted away from you, I'm just trying to exist in the hostile environment that you forced me into. If you weren't shouting, I wouldn't have to.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
When I looked behind me there was a kid with ear defenders on.

I hope you didn't shout at them too.

I wish there was understanding that some people need time and patience to think and move and do, instead of shouting to move along. I get why you do it. 

Please remember this.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

tweet:
Dear TSA Agent,

Yelling at me well not make me go faster.

Yes I have headphones on.

Yes I can hear you.

No, I can't think because you're spouting words at 10 times a second.

When you said "yes take those off" I put them back on b/c you shouted and I needed to take shoes off.

I wear over-the-ear headphones when I go out. This dampens most (95%) of the loud sounds that would hurt my ears to manageable levels. For louder venues I use earplugs, or earplugs + headphones. 

If you want more info on hyperacusis in autism, see:
https://t.co/9k01A3qXci

6/6

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
So please do not tell them that exposure therapy is the only way or that they're making up their pain! Give them ALL the options. 

Let them know that there is not much research on autism and hyperacusis because that's important to know!

#Audiology #ENT

5/6

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Don't assume that it can -only- be anxiety-based. This is a real thing! It's real pain!

My anxiety came from the pain. If I didn't have pain, I wouldn't be anxious. 

Ear protection nearly completely eliminated my anxiety in relation to my hyperacusis.

4/6

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
There is VERY little research on autistic people and hyperacusis so please do not assume that it is the same as hyperacusis acquired from hearing loss.

I've had pain with loud noises literally since I can remember. It's likely very different.

3/6

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I'm not saying it -can't- make it worse, but autistic people without hearing loss who have hyperacusis may have it for a different reason. 

In my last 4 years of wearing ear protection, my hyperacusis has never "gotten worse" because of it. I wear headphones when I go out.

2/6

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Hey #Audiologists - Please remember this and spread the word:

Autistic people can have hyperacusis without hearing loss! 

In fact, about 60% of autistic adults do based on a recent literature review!

Also, do your research - don't assume ear protection will make it worse.

1/6

tweet:
@laurenancona Misophonia has been found to correlate with an increase in the anterior insula. Basically it triggers anger/wanting to immediately stop the sound. & can be quiet sounds.

Whereas hyperacusis is ear pain because sounds are too loud/painful.

tweet: @trewvs I'm not sure I can explain it in one tweet but it basically has to do with the hair cells in the cochlea dying from hearing loss and the auditory system sort of "compensating" for that.

@MelobuniiP Generally neurotypical people acquire hyperacusis often when they develop hearing loss. So that's where all the research is,

even though autistic people from what I've read basically have this when they're born and even without hearing loss for many of us.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

tweet:

I've had this pain with loud sounds since I can remember rather than acquiring it.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
@TallerThanSoul Those, in my opinion, are 2 separate things.

Reduced filtering doesn't have to do with volume.

Hyperacusis has to do with other people thinking sounds are quiet but are actually too loud and uncomfortable/painful for you.

I talk about this here - https://t.co/bzbZBggglj

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

tweet:
And btw, I'm not saying that the low-noise generators -never- help people, sometimes they can. 

But if you're autistic and you have other auditory conditions like reduced filtering or reduced habituation, even "quiet" white noise could be overwhelming.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: @leahmcelrath Oh ok, I guess I was confused because you put "loud" in quotes. Hyperacusis is when sounds are perceived as loud to the person with hyperacusis - so even if they aren't loud to other people, they are loud to you regardless.

description:

tweet:
@leahmcelrath So that's the issue - the term hyperacusis actually IS specific to loud sounds. But people throw it around to mean "auditory sensitivity" generally when it's not.

What you're describing is likely misophonia if it's to specific quiet sounds.

@thekawaiislarti White noise is generally the worst, and then high-frequency sounds as well. My threshold of pain is much better for lower frequencies like 1000 Hz. It's still lower than someone without hyperacusis but not by as much.

It's different for each person but still related to loudness.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

tweet:
To clarify what hyperacusis is, it is pain/discomfort from loud sounds.

Based on when I've asked this in the past, 

For autistic people, it can range from loud sounds feeling like an ice pick is stabbing your eardrum (what I get) to getting throbbing headaches/migraines.

I really wish they would include autistic people who do not have hearing loss as part of that research.

description:

tweet:
I can personally attest to this myself, because I tested myself in an audiology booth once and my threshold of pain with broadband white noise was 60 dB SPL.

I wrote it was loud at 40 dB, uncomfortable at 45-50 dB, on the edge of pain at 55 dB, and clear pain at 60 dB.

10/12

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Also, the hyperacusis autistic people without hearing loss experience is often at a lower threshold than non-autistic people. 

Meaning that, on average, we experience pain/discomfort at lower sounds levels than NTs who acquire hyperacusis from hearing loss.

9/12

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

tweet:
I got an email about recently funded hyperacusis research and nearly every single model based on hearing loss.

Many, many autistic people have hyperacusis without hearing loss.

Therefore, the mechanism of the hyperacusis we experience could be very different.

And I'm guessing that many of them do not have hearing loss (based on a separate study in autistic kids with hyperacusis).

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

@robinmcstay Being highly effective and being emotionally healthy years later is not the same thing.

It may be helpful but not because of the Social Mapping Formula - it's because he understands WHY and it's centered on what he wants to do. Those are not things that exist in other programs.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

tweet:

I.e. Autistic people could interact differently and still reach the same conclusion, but it's never going to be taught that way because "this is what NTs expect you to do."

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

tweet:
Every single exchanged became a calculation to solve and what I didn't realize for so long was that I could never solve it because it wasn't solvable. It was a trick. A trap. A way to control me. A way to get what they wanted without regard to me as a human. 

I Could Never Win.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: I am so angry that I was not treated like a human being and I can never get that back. I am so angry that academia allows graduate students to feel like this and it's somehow a necessity to "become a scholar." I am so angry that nothing changes even in a pandemic. I am so angry.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: It made me think I was worthless, that nothing I did was good enough, that actually my life was worth nothing. All because a person told me I was the one who could reach the milestone on my own while pulling the rug out from under me everytime I reached out for support.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Everytime I asserted a boundary it would be steamrolled.

Or it would be respected until the waters were calm and the person decided to steamroll me unexpectedly, when I didn't see it coming. I don't think I've ever experienced this kind of manipulation until the past year.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: I was swindled out of my physical, emotional, & mental energy in a mind game trying to please a person who had completely impossible expectations who had power over me because our academic system has no recourse. Because no one would believe me. Because my anger was "irrational."

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: It was someone telling me I had control, but when I tried to exert that control, I was told I was being unreasonable. When I had a dissenting opinion I was told I was wrong. Everything I did was either wrong or not enough, or "keep going" basically until it killed me.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA

When what that really meant was I had no choice to begin with & must do X or else

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience.

tweet:
10. Be open about your own needs as an allistic person.

Don't do things that you aren't comfortable with, like eating spicy food that might upset your stomach, just because X person made it.

By advocating for your own needs, you're showing other people that it's okay to do so.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
9. Bust myths.
If autism comes up around the dinner table, let them know that these things are incorrect:
"Well everyone's a little bit on the spectrum"
Assuming autistic people can't interact with people or hold a conversation.
Assuming trans people/women/BIPOC can't be autistic

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
8. Provide other people with a new perspective on situations that are often prone to judgment.

For example, if your relative is telling someone to "pay attention" or to stop fidgeting, let your relative know that some people need to fidget, or look away, to emotionally regulate.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: 7. If someone's wearing headphones, playing on a Switch, wants to be away from the party for a few hours, or doesn't want to eat specific food you made - maybe consider that the person is not trying to be rude but needs to conserve their energy or has food sensitivities.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: 6. If you interact with someone & immediately have an emotional reaction to them when the entire exchange was something like "how are you?" or just a greeting - think about why. If you see them looking away from you but they're responding to you, don't assume they're uninterested

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: 5. Stop yourself before you make assumptions about someone. If there's a child running around or being very loud, don't assume the parent is bad or the child has "behavioral issues." It's likely their needs aren't being met.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
4. Especially during the holidays - let people know about autistic-run nonprofits and autistic-run businesses, and if a harmful organization comes up, make sure to tell them that it's not helpful to autistic people. 

This is very important because most people don't know this.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: 3. Correct others if they make jokes about how certain people are being "awkward" or "weird." Remind them that people may interact differently and to possibly be more direct to the person they're interacting with if they want to be left alone or wanted to leave the interaction.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: 2. Assume that autistic people exist in the spaces that you access. Don't make the assumption you will only interact with neurotypical people in certain spaces. Whatever job you work in, there's probably an autistic person working there (or many!).

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

Not all of us are out as autistic, so sharing is vital!

An experimenter tapped on a box, and then opened it. The neurotypical children watched and then did the same thing. 

The autistic children didn't tap. 
They just opened the box.

They concluded autistic kids had "poor theory of mind."

8/

8/8

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA

7/8

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

This is stress and anxiety that I shouldn't have and it's become my norm.

6/8

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

5/8

4/8

tweet:
My nervous system has been on overdrive since I was really young. 

I have to learn to
1. Recognize body signals
2. Interpret them
3. Know how to accommodate myself
4. Recognize when I subconsciously inhibit my needs
5. Consciously override it
6. Soothe my nervous system

This also helps me understand that more often than not, allistic people will probably interpret my tone of voice/body language and implicit meaning of words as intentional.

It's scary to realize just how different we are & just how often & to what level people judge us.

8/13

description:

tweet:
Even if the word "masking" wasn't used, I think allistic people would still assume our actions are intentional.

It makes me wonder if allistic people often intentionally manipulate others? But only sometimes recognize that they do this once it's talked about?

7/13

5/13

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
She said something like "well everyone does that, and uses some masking - not to the same extent - to manipulate someone to get what they want."

I explained that it's not intentional, it's a trauma response to how we're treated and she said oh that makes sense, and agreed.

4/13

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
She said that "masking" is a bad name because in her mind, she would immediately think that it was about changing how you present to "manipulate" someone to get what you want.

To me, it's interesting how masking immediately is assumed to be intentional to her.

3/13

Very few people will support your decision. 

Do it anyway. Most of them will have no idea what you are going through. No understanding of your barriers. Good intentions doesn't fix that.

You Always have the option to leave. If you feel like you don't, something's wrong.
3/3

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
If you wake up wanting to die every morning, leave. If you have passive suicidal thoughts related to your work/school, leave.

People will tell you that mental health is important but it will not be what they are really saying. It will be tacked on.
2/3

tweet:
We are allowed to speak up as long as it is comfortable for non-autistic people. As long as we don't point fingers or don't speak some harsh truths.

So no, I will not be giving "a few minutes of my time" right now. Instead I have spent those minutes writing this thread.

12/12

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
We are allowed to give "free input" that they either accept, ignore, or refuse.

We are allowed to tell our stories only filtered through a non-autistic lens, if we want views.

We are allowed to be the spokespeople only for things which do us harm (A$, ABA, Spectrum10k).

11/12

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Autistic people aren't allowed to have our own narrative.

We're not allowed to have our own voice represented in journalism, moves, tv shows.

We're not allowed to design and co-produce research that impacts our lives and often even causes harm.

10/12

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

9/12

7/12

5/12

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

It is never only "a few minutes" of our time. It is constant inquiries about what we think, so that you can make something "for us," or write something "about us."

4/12

3/12

Recently I got asked to give input for some sort of design or study from a graduate student. I was asked if I could answer a couple of questions about X and just give my personal opinion and experience.

1/12

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: Just meeting them I instantly started crying. I didn't even know I was autistic then but I knew I wouldn't be able to talk (was a shutdown), and I had to show them my question with a notebook that I wrote it in as a backup.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: I tried to speak twice every week and even then it was a struggle to get a word in. At some point, I was so anxious about my grade that I met with the professor (had to be in person as of course this couldn't be answered through my original email question..)

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: This reminded me of the time that I was getting C's in my first discussion class in graduate school. I didn't know the professor who taught it very well. There were 15 students in the class all trying to get their participation in and people would interrupt each other.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Basically this meant - these students really care about their grades and want to do well, so you can take a few points off and then they will definitely work even harder to gain them back.

So if they're putting in more effort than average, make them put in even more?!

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I'll tell you a story -
For a class I helped with we have participation points. I was told at some point that we can take points off if they're not doing as well as we'd want them to or not 100% on task. I was told that this is okay because they're "high achievers."

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: And of course these road blocks are very much not equal but we are taught that they are, that these milestones are equal, no matter what your support system, economic status, race, gender, religion, etc. is. And it's just honestly ridiculous.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: And we're also taught that these artificial (and a lot of other -isms) road blocks that pop up during graduate school are part of the journey and that if you don't "overcome" them you don't deserve the education because you didn't "fight for it."

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
So you can't tell people easily, and if you do you can't expect sympathy because sometimes it does sound ridiculous.

And academia constantly reinforces the idea that you -need- X/Y/Z to survive, to live, to be a "productive" human being. So it's easy for your brain to believe it

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
You know, one of the worst things about your mental health tanking when you're in grad school is that when you kind of "zoom out" and possibly to other people,

your struggles look ridiculous and overblown. But academia constantly teaches you that you NEED it to live.

Functioning. Labels. Are. Bull. Sh*t.

tweet:
What I didn't hear in my life -

It's okay to fail!
We'll be here no matter what happens.
I'm here if you want me to listen to your concerns.
We're not going anywhere.
It's okay to feel anxious/worried/scared about this.
It's okay if things don't go well.

17/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Being autistic inherently means being unlikeable and abrasive in our current society. That's what it means to be myself. To be brutally honest, too much, annoying. 
Perfectionism was all I had that people congratulated. So failure wasn't an option.

I want it to be an option.
16/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

Perfection shouldn't be the meaning of life. 
16/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

tweet:

Would we think it's "lazy" behavior? Would it be seen as bad? Are people who fail "not enough"?

15/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

tweet:

14/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
This might sound silly, but I never knew that failing was an option. Only in college did I start actively trying to be less perfectionist than I was, to intentionally not give 100% when I knew it didn't matter. I could barely do it. I'd try to be proud of myself when I did.

13/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Even as an adult I think the people around me will hate me if I fail. Not necessarily my immediate family (maybe they'll just be disappointed), but friends, peers.

It's not a rational feeling. It's a feeling my body learned growing up and continues to learn. 

12/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I want to know that people will still care about me and support me when I fail. I want to know that they'll have my back. I want to know that failing isn't the end of the world.

But it never gets any easier because I was never told these things & I don't have the evidence.

11/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
"Practice makes perfect."
"If you keep doing it you'll get better, it'll be easier."

Even growing up, I knew this was a lie for certain things in my life, like presentations. I couldn't explain why but I knew it was a lie. I got told it wasn't over and over again.

10/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
People talk about how when you do something a few times it gets easier.

For me, some things never ever get easier. They never do. It's the same anxiety every time. How will they interpret my autistic traits? 

Whatever I do can't predict or change that perception.

9/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA

6/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

they stop supporting you because they don't think you "need" it. They stop treating you as someone who could fail. 

And the stakes feel even higher then.

5/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

4/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
When you get praised for being perfect, for never failing, for always being dependable,

you always wonder if once you mess up, the people in your life who cared about you and supported you will be gone. That they won't care or won't like you anymore or won't support you.

3/

You'll be fine!
You're an expert at this!
You can do this!
You deserve it!
Don't worry about it, it's not a big deal.
Don't be so negative!
You're so smart!

It probably looks like encouragement.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
It may not be what abled people think they're saying, but that is what disabled people are seeing. That is what the impact of your words mean to us when you are "back to normal."

You get to be grateful and get back to your life like usual, like it never happened.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet: It simply reminds me that people in society, including abled people with temporary injuries that heal, still think of disabled people as lesser than. That they have higher status because they will once again be an abled person& only abled people can be valuable.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
When I see those posts I think "how many people would still support you if you couldn't do X/Y/Z your whole life instead of for 1-4 months?"

I see the clear internalized ableism that if it were permanent, they would feel like a burden and feel useless.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I understand that temporary injuries can still have effects on your life. But I see people treat it as if it is some sort of test of will that they got through or being so grateful to people supporting them.

But for some of us that's our baseline forever.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
It's only a burden to other people of there's a time limit on their help.

If there's not.. If you don't "get better"... You have to deal with everyone else's feelings about having a permanent disability too. Everyone's expectations. Everyone's fears. Everyone's frustrations.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

tweet:
Regardless of the reason, all it brings is shame, lower self-esteem, and anxiety about how you exist in the world in every moment.

The scary thing about being autistic is that you spend years, just like Ani Spooner did, pretending you are someone else.

10/18

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
When you're taught so early on that people want you to be something else, it's nearly impossible not to give in to that. Sometimes it's because people want your life to be "easier." Other times it's because they want -their- life to be easier around you.

9/18

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
But this anxiety of "Will people still like me? Will I still seem worthy to them?" is something that is not talked about enough, and I think it's true for any minority group that has to hide who they are in our majority society.

8/18

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
There's not one moment where people look at me and decide I'm different, unless there's a visible marker - like I'm wearing headphones. 

I can't just tell someone "this is who I am" and have them get it. Most of the time even when they think they understand, they don't.
7/18

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
The way it was expressed in this segment was so clear & so important.

To me, it's hard when it's not something visible (like all of my disabilities, actually, unless I'm showing people my foot),

Because then claiming an identity or showing who you are is seen as a choice.
6/18

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
If you can "hide" your disability, you are always taught that you should, no matter how inconvenient it is for you.

As an autistic person, this feeling of "Will people still like me?" and this anxiety about self-worth is so engrained. 
5/18

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
At 34 years old, she finally decided to stop applying the makeup everyday.

This feeling of "will people still like me if I show who I am?" is so relatable and so deep to me. I think it is for many disabled people who can "hide" their disability. 
4/18

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I have one sticky note on my monitor and it says "You are not indebted to anyone."

I always feel like I owe other people something.

I don't.

I owe it to myself to be kind to me, and to take care of myself in whatever way that looks like for me.

Not to meet impossible demands.

Remind yourself to let go their conditional relationship with you.

tweet:

A few people every once in a while will understand and give you grace, but otherwise it's people being upset at you.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

We are not the same as you.

You can relate to some of our experience.

That does not mean you have autistic burnout.
That does not mean you have autistic stress.

Allow us to have our own narrative and space. 
Stop watering it down to your experience.

Let us have our own.
7/7

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

tweet: @SupernovaMomma Like "You don't want to brush your teeth" - it isn't just a "don't want" most of the time, especially for autistic kids. It's "You really have a hard time brushing your teeth because of the awful bristles and toothpaste and it's hard to hold."

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
@SupernovaMomma Adults get to change their own plans. They get to move environments or leave places if they need to. They get to change the meal that night if they're not interested.

Of course there are limits, but it's weird to me how much control we put over children, & expect them to agree.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
@SupernovaMomma Reminding them again, at least for anxious autistic kids, is just going to set off another round of anxiety if they can't do that thing right now/aren't in the emotional state to do so.

I don't know why we expect children to be more emotionally mature than adults are.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

Most kids already know what they need to do.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

So we use the words "autistic burnout"

But I'm realizing that it's not just burnout like neurotypical people define it,

It's burnout -past- burnout. It's working while in burnout already.

That's why it's so difference and so detrimental. We're not stopping at burnout at all.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Using the word "tired" doesn't do what I'm feeling justice.

I have a sleep disorder, I know what tired, sleepy, exhausted means.

It's more like completely worn down, especially mentally. But my brain still thinks "I have 5% energy left so it's fine"

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I'm going to pay for this in being able to physically speak, in being able to think coherently, in being able to plan, in being able to eat.

I just know I'm going to pay for this but there is no other option.

So often, there is not another option for us.
#ActuallyAutistic 

12/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:

but all I can think about right now, all I know is that I'm going to pay for this. When I keep going this next week, and the next, and the next, I'm going to pay for this.

11/

description:

When we say we can't and then they tell us to do it anyway?

10/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
At this point I don't even know if 1-2 days of rest would help because I'm already so far gone in terms of stress and energy levels (I've been trying to work at least one day every weekend).

I think I would need a week off, and I can't afford a week off right now. So I work.
9/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
If I reflect on my current energy levels and stress, I'm probably in burn out right now.

But all I'm thinking is "Well I just need to get to this part and then I'll rest.." or "I just need to finish these next 3 weeks out and then I'll rest.."
8/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Only to later realize, weeks or months later, that I have smoke coming out of the engine.

THAT'S when I realize I should stop the car.
I don't even have a "gas is empty" indicator on my dashboard, I just know if I don't go 60 miles per hour people are going to be upset.
7/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I don't just "burn out" when I run out of energy, I go until the gas tank has negative space.

Here's the difference for autistics:
I don't realize in the moment that I'm running on empty. I think I still have plenty of fuel left to get me going somewhere.
6/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I don't know if abled non-autistic people realize how long I can run on fumes for. Because I'm so used to that being expected of me. 

And I do think dissociating plays a role in being able to do this.
5/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Most autistic people operate on a higher level of stress at a constant rate.

Neurotypical people will have lows, mediums, and highs. Sometimes they'll stay at a high for a long time and burn out.

But autistic people are never allowed low stress if we want to be seen as human
4/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
And so often autistic people are constantly pushed to their limits even at 4, 5, 8 years old. Constantly. 

We are so often already at a level of stress from NT expectations and our environment that neurotypical people don't even comprehend it. 
3/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I was told that if I get burnt out, I won't be able to do anything, so I should rest.

What I didn't say because I was still thinking it through,
is that when I get burnt out, I go on for weeks or months more because that is expected of me and I Cannot Let People Down.
2/

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
I think I just realized why autistic burnout is so bad.

It's because when neurotypical people reach their limits, they can't go on.

When autistic people reach their limits, they continue because they know they have to continue to be considered valuable.
1/
