tweet:
The weight of humiliating an autistic person for their interests is enormous.

For many of us it is the medium through which we connect to the world.

If you think it's weird or funny, keep it to yourself.

I'm being honest when I say that this can be traumatic to many of us.
9/9

Don't intentionally make a stimulus to "see their reaction."
Don't continue to do something when they are clearly becoming distressed, saying no, or withdrawing from whatever you are doing.
Don't stand directly in front of or behind an autistic person when not asked to.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
Things this would include:

Don't touch an autistic person without consent.
Don't have multiple people talking to the autistic person at once.
Don't put your arms really close next to the autistic person.
Don't physically move an autistic person.
Don't complain when they say no.

tweet:
Stop using functioning labels. It helps absolutely no one. 

And you would never use them on a neurotypical person in the same way.

When you say "high functioning" I hear "not really autistic."

When you say "low functioning" I hear "not human and not valuable."

Stop it.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

tweet: I'm only deemed "high-functioning" because other people can't see the illusion of independence. They don't see me "at my worst" (i.e. most stressed, shutdown/meltdown). They don't realize how much help my spouse is around daily chores, or how my parents help me with phone calls.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

tweet: I'm only "high-functioning" because I've been supported growing up in privilege, where people didn't talk down to me or openly stigmatizing me. Where I could get support in the education system and have a respite through the "gifted" program.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

I am not "independent."
I may not live with my family members, I may go to grad school, but I am not "independent." And no one is, when they are under stress or when they meet their limitations.

This is another reason why functioning labels are completely misleading.

Not knowing how to socialize in a neurotypical way in a neurotypical-dominated cultural society 

is not the same as not knowing how, or not being able, to socialize at all.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

tweet:
Autistic people existing together in a space is autistic sociality.

The same would be said for neurotypical people existing in a space. 

Autistic people are social. We interact with humans. The idea that we don't have a social way of being or don't know how is ludicrous.

Terms we don't hear enough:

Autistic social cues
Autistic body language
Autistic gestures
Autistic tone of voice
Autistic facial expressions.

Reminder that we have all of those.

When people say autistics need to "learn social skills" they think we don't have them. 

We do.

What #Spectrum10K is (from my perspective)-

1. A re-contactable genetic database.
2. Will be combined likely with SPARK.
3. Most questionnaires are optional.
4. Want to find autism genes.
5. No direct benefit to participants.
6. No clear future benefits to autistic people.
6/

Collecting genetic data of a very specific subset of autistic people who have official diagnoses will always be biased.

Using questionnaires made by NTs to describe autistic "behavior" will always be biased.
1/10

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

but I will say fuck off to anyone who complains that my shoes look ugly and I need different ones or they're not appropriate for the occasion.

I'd rather not be in pain everytime I take one step,
thank you.

tweet:

They'd tell me I need to get foot surgery (part of the reason I tried it - 3 week recovery).

Now they tell me my shoes look ugly.

and my venous malformation doesn't hurt me, 
and doesn't hurt me the next day,

I thank my weird-looking, very ugly toe shoes. 💜

Restricted behavior: limited in focus, interest, or activity, such as preoccupation with a single television program, toy, or game.

Self-injury: includes movements that injure or can injure the person, such as eye poking, skin picking, hand biting, and head banging.

Results - 

This is what they found for those people -
"higher PGS for autism was associated with reduced count of co-occurring developmental disabilities "

The more common genes you had with other people in the autistic group, the less co-occurring conditions you had.

10/21

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
So what are they actually looking at?

They're looking at "polygenic scores" (PGS) - basically, they took a bunch of genetic data from autistic people, and tried to see if they shared the same genes. Autistic people with the same genes had "high autism polygenic scores."

tweet:
to sleep, do that 2 more times, wake up at noon, try to focus eyes, get up, 

be completely exhausted for the rest of the day. Spend 4-5 hours just trying to do anything to wake up with the energy that I have left or feel mildly awake. Feel sleepy.

That's a hypersomnia day.

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:
Autistic writer and speaker with a Masters in Neuroscience. 

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
For anyone who's wondering what a "bad hypersomnia day" is, my version is like this:

Wake up with nystagmus, eyes moving everywhere, can't focus on anything, close eyes, go back to sleep, experience sleep paralysis, dream of trying to wake up, wake up with nystagmus, go back..

1. youtube videos/podcasts of 1-on-1 conversations.
2. music I like with lyrics
3. video game soundtracks
4. lofi hiphop
5. rain sounds
6. brown noise
7. nothing

tweet:
That's what autistic people are taught, even without explicit ABA.
It's how our bodies and minds are programmed because it is how we have survived. 
And autistic people of color have this on even higher alert because situations can become life-threatening in an instant.
3/3

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc

tweet:
Although this is autism-related, it bleeds over into other areas - when people misgender me who know my pronouns, I default to not saying anything every single time. I can't make myself do it.

It's like if I'm not getting steamrolled by other people I'm not "being nice."
2/3

name: AutisticSciencePerson, MSc
description:

white, nonbinary. they/them Opinions are my own & do not represent my employer. #SayNoToABA
tweet:
It's amazing just how much work we constantly put in to make other people feel more comfortable around us.

Even after I've done so much processing, I know when I get into an uncomfortable NT-acquaintance situation my body and brain will hide itself to avoid conflict.
1/3
